statement: I believe everyone should be able to see a doctor and afford basic medical care, but I don’t think a one-size-fits-all, fully government-run system is the answer. The government’s role should be to set fair rules, protect people with preexisting conditions, and provide a safety net for those who truly can’t afford coverage, while allowing private insurers and employers to compete and innovate. We ought to focus on lowering costs through transparency, personal responsibility, and encouraging healthier lifestyles, rather than just shifting the bill to taxpayers.

statement: As a nurse in a nonprofit hospital, I see every day how lack of coverage or delayed care harms patients, especially working families and kids. I believe the government should guarantee universal access to basic, high‑quality healthcare—through a strong public framework and regulation—so no one’s ability to see a doctor depends on their job, income, or ZIP code. Private providers and insurers can still have a role, but the baseline of preventive care, emergency care, and essential treatments should be a right, not a privilege. That aligns with my faith, my commitment to helping others, and my belief that a healthier population also strengthens our schools, workforce, and communities.

statement: Growing up working-class and seeing how easily an injury or illness can wreck someone’s life, I think the government has a responsibility to guarantee universal access to healthcare, at least at a basic level, so no one is choosing between rent and going to the doctor. As a Catholic, I see healthcare as a matter of human dignity and solidarity, not just a product you buy if you’re lucky enough to afford it. I’m fine with private options existing on top, but the baseline should be publicly guaranteed, affordable, and simple to use, especially for people doing physical work like me.

Ensuring that no one has to forgo care or go into deep debt because they get sick is, to me, a moral obligation of a just society.

statement: As someone who works the land and depends on a healthy body to support my family, I believe access to basic healthcare should be guaranteed for everyone, regardless of income or where they live. The government should provide a universal baseline of coverage—especially preventive and primary care—so people don’t end up in crisis before they can see a doctor. Private options can exist on top of that, but no one should be choosing between medical bills and putting food on the table. A healthier population also means less strain on our communities and more capacity to care for the land and environment we all depend on.

statement: At my age, having worked as a nurse for decades, I’ve seen too many people delay care or skip medicines because they couldn’t afford them, and it breaks my heart and my sense of fairness. I believe the government has a responsibility to guarantee universal access to healthcare as a basic right, funded through taxes, so no one is left choosing between rent, food, and seeing a doctor. A wealthy country like ours can and should ensure that everyone, regardless of income or job, can get the care they need without fear of financial ruin.

statement: I think the government should make sure everyone can get basic healthcare, because nobody should have to skip the doctor just because their family doesn’t have enough money. My parents work hard and we have insurance, but I know not everyone is that lucky, and it doesn’t seem fair that kids could get really sick just because of cost. The government should at least cover important stuff like emergencies, checkups, and vaccines, and then families who want more can choose extra coverage if they can afford it.
